subject: Economics
title: Thomas Malthus: The Population Bomb
description: One-minute skill: Thomas Malthus: The Population Bomb.

hook.text: In 1798, Malthus predicted humanity was doomed. Population grows exponentially; food grows linearly.

buildup.text: His math seemed irrefutable: population doubles every 25 years, but farmland doesn't.

discovery.text: The 'Malthusian trap' did describe all of human history until 1800. For millennia, more people just meant more poverty.

twist.text: Then industrialization shattered his prediction. Technology increased food production faster than population growth.

climax.text: Malthus gave economics its nickname: 'the dismal science.' He was wrong about the future but right about the past.

punchline.text: The most famous prediction in economics was spectacularly wrong.

quiz.question: Why was Malthus's prediction ultimately wrong?
options: Technological innovation increased food production faster than population growth
